003import squidpony.LZSPlus;
004import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
005import squidpony.squidmath.*;
006import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise2D;

010import java.io.Serializable;

013/**
014 * Can be used to generate world maps with a wide variety of data, starting with height, temperature and moisture.
015 * From there, you can determine biome information in as much detail as your game needs, with default implementations
016 * available; one assigns a single biome to each cell based on heat/moisture, and the other gives a gradient between two
017 * biome types for every cell. The maps this produces with {@link SphereMap} are valid for spherical world projections,
018 * while the maps from {@link TilingMap} are for toroidal world projections and will wrap from edge to opposite edge
019 * seamlessly thanks to <a href="https://www.gamedev.net/blog/33/entry-2138456-seamless-noise/">a technique from the
020 * Accidental Noise Library</a> that involves getting a 2D slice of 4D Simplex noise. Because of how Simplex noise
021 * works, this also allows extremely high zoom levels for all types of map as long as certain parameters are within
022 * reason. Other world maps produce more conventional shapes, like {@link SpaceViewMap} and {@link RotatingSpaceMap}
023 * make a view of a marble-like world from space, and others make more unconventional shapes, like {@link EllipticalMap}
024 * or {@link EllipticalHammerMap}, which form a 2:1 ellipse shape that accurately keeps sizes but not relative shapes,
025 * {@link RoundSideMap}, which forms a pill-shape, and {@link HyperellipticalMap}, which takes parameters so it can fit
026 * any shape between a circle or ellipse and a rectangle (the default is a slightly squared-off ellipse). You can access
027 * the height map with the {@link #heightData} field, the heat map with the {@link #heatData} field, the moisture map
028 * with the {@link #moistureData} field, and a special map that stores ints representing the codes for various ranges of
029 * elevation (0 to 8 inclusive, with 0 the deepest ocean and 8 the highest mountains) with {@link #heightCodeData}. The
030 * last map should be noted as being the simplest way to find what is land and what is water; any height code 4 or
031 * greater is land, and any height code 3 or less is water.
032 * <br>
033 * Biome mapping is likely to need customization per-game, but some good starting points are {@link SimpleBiomeMapper},
034 * which stores one biome per cell, and {@link DetailedBiomeMapper}, which gives each cell a midway value between two
035 * biomes.
036 */
037@Beta
038public abstract class WorldMapGenerator implements Serializable {
039    private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
040    public final int width, height;
041    public int seedA, seedB, cacheA, cacheB;
042    public GWTRNG rng;
043    public final double[][] heightData, heatData, moistureData;
044    public final GreasedRegion landData;
045    public final int[][] heightCodeData;
046    public double landModifier = -1.0, heatModifier = 1.0,
047            minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
048            minHeightActual = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeightActual = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
049            minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
050            minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
051    protected double centerLongitude = 0.0;
052
053    /**
054     * Gets the longitude line the map is centered on, which should usually be between 0 and 2 * PI.
055     * @return the longitude line the map is centered on, in radians from 0 to 2 * PI
056     */
057    public double getCenterLongitude() {
058        return centerLongitude;
059    }
060
061    /**
062     * Sets the center longitude line to a longitude measured in radians, from 0 to 2 * PI. Positive arguments will be
063     * corrected with modulo, but negative ones may not always act as expected, and are strongly discouraged.
064     * @param centerLongitude the longitude to center the map projection on, from 0 to 2 * PI (can be any non-negative double).
065     */
066    public void setCenterLongitude(double centerLongitude) {
067        this.centerLongitude = centerLongitude % 6.283185307179586;
068    }
069
070    public int zoom = 0, startX = 0, startY = 0, usedWidth, usedHeight;
071    protected IntVLA startCacheX = new IntVLA(8), startCacheY = new IntVLA(8);
072    protected int zoomStartX = 0, zoomStartY = 0;
073    public static final double
074            deepWaterLower = -1.0, deepWaterUpper = -0.7,        // 0
075            mediumWaterLower = -0.7, mediumWaterUpper = -0.3,    // 1
076            shallowWaterLower = -0.3, shallowWaterUpper = -0.1,  // 2
077            coastalWaterLower = -0.1, coastalWaterUpper = 0.02,   // 3
078            sandLower = 0.02, sandUpper = 0.12,                   // 4
079            grassLower = 0.14, grassUpper = 0.35,                // 5
080            forestLower = 0.35, forestUpper = 0.6,               // 6
081            rockLower = 0.6, rockUpper = 0.8,                    // 7
082            snowLower = 0.8, snowUpper = 1.0;                    // 8
083
084    protected static double removeExcess(double radians)
085    {
086        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
087        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1);
088        return (radians - (floor & -2) - ((floor & 1) << 1)) * (Math.PI);
089//        if(radians < -Math.PI || radians > Math.PI)
090//            System.out.println("UH OH, radians produced: " + radians);
091//        if(Math.random() < 0.00001)
092//            System.out.println(radians);
093//        return radians;
094
095    }
096    /**
097     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
098     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
099     * Always makes a 256x256 map. If you were using {@link WorldMapGenerator#WorldMapGenerator(long, int, int)}, then
100     * this would be the same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256}.
101     */
102    protected WorldMapGenerator()
103    {
104        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256);
105    }
106    /**
107     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
108     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
109     * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
110     * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
111     * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
112     *
113     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
114     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
115     */
116    protected WorldMapGenerator(int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
117    {
118        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight);
119    }
120    /**
121     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
122     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
123     * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
124     * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
125     * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
126     *
127     * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
128     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
129     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
130     */
131    protected WorldMapGenerator(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
132    {
133        width = mapWidth;
134        height = mapHeight;
135        usedWidth = width;
136        usedHeight = height;
137        seedA = (int) (initialSeed & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
138        seedB = (int) (initialSeed >>> 32);
139        cacheA = ~seedA;
140        cacheB = ~seedB;
141        rng = new GWTRNG(seedA, seedB);
142        heightData = new double[width][height];
143        heatData = new double[width][height];
144        moistureData = new double[width][height];
145        landData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
146//        riverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
147//        lakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
148//        partialRiverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
149//        partialLakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
150//        workingData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
151        heightCodeData = new int[width][height];
152    }
153
154    /**
155     * Generates a world using a random RNG state and all parameters randomized.
156     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
157     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
158     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
159     */
160    public void generate()
161    {
162        generate(rng.nextLong());
163    }
164
165    /**
166     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long. Other parameters will be randomized, using the same
167     * RNG state to start with.
168     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
169     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
170     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
171     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
172     */
173    public void generate(long state) {
174        generate(-1.0, -1.0, state);
175    }
176
177    /**
178     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long, with specific land and heat modifiers that affect
179     * the land-water ratio and the average temperature, respectively.
180     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
181     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
182     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
183     * @param landMod 1.0 is Earth-like, less than 1 is more-water, more than 1 is more-land; a random value will be used if this is negative
184     * @param heatMod 1.125 is Earth-like, less than 1 is cooler, more than 1 is hotter; a random value will be used if this is negative
185     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
186     */
187    public void generate(double landMod, double heatMod, long state)
188    {
189        if(cacheA != (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL) || cacheB != (int) (state >>> 32) ||
190                landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
191        {
192            seedA = (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
193            seedB = (int) (state >>> 32);
194            zoom = 0;
195            startCacheX.clear();
196            startCacheY.clear();
197            startCacheX.add(0);
198            startCacheY.add(0);
199            zoomStartX = width >> 1;
200            zoomStartY = height >> 1;
201
202        }
203        //System.out.printf("generate, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
204
205        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
206                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
207                usedWidth = (width >> zoom), usedHeight = (height >> zoom), landMod, heatMod, seedA, seedB);
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
212     * version of zoomOut always zooms out from the center of the currently used area.
213     * <br>
214     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
215     */
216    public void zoomOut()
217    {
218        zoomOut(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
219    }
220    /**
221     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers repeatedly, halving {@code zoomAmount} times; the
222     * 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomOut allows you to specify where the zoom should be
223     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
224     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
225     * <br>
226     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
227     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
228     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
229     */
230    public void zoomOut(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
231    {
232        zoomAmount = Math.min(zoom, zoomAmount);
233        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
234        if(zoomAmount < 0) {
235            zoomIn(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
236            return;
237        }
238        if(zoom > 0)
239        {
240            if(cacheA != seedA || cacheB != seedB)
241            {
242                generate(rng.nextLong());
243            }
244            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
245                    (zoomStartX + (zoomCenterX - (width >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
246                    width >> 1), (width << zoom - zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
247            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
248                    (zoomStartY + (zoomCenterY - (height >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
249                    height >> 1), (height << zoom - zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
250//            System.out.printf("zoomOut, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
251            zoom -= zoomAmount;
252            startCacheX.pop();
253            startCacheY.pop();
254            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.pop() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
255                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
256            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.pop() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
257                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
258//            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartX >> 1) + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
259//                    0), width - (width >> zoom));
260//            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartY >> 1) + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
261//                    0), height - (height >> zoom));
262            regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> zoom + 1), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> zoom + 1),
263                    //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
264                    usedWidth = width >> zoom,  usedHeight = height >> zoom,
265                    landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
266            rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
267        }
268
269    }
270    /**
271     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
272     * version of zoomIn always zooms in to the center of the currently used area.
273     * <br>
274     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
275     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
276     * normal landscape.
277     */
278    public void zoomIn()
279    {
280        zoomIn(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
281    }
282    /**
283     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers repeatedly, doubling {@code zoomAmount} times;
284     * the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomIn allows you to specify where the zoom should be
285     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
286     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
287     * <br>
288     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
289     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
290     * normal landscape.
291     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
292     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
293     */
294    public void zoomIn(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
295    {
296        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
297        if(zoomAmount < 0)
298        {
299            zoomOut(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
300            return;
301        }
302        if(seedA != cacheA || seedB != cacheB)
303        {
304            generate(rng.nextLong());
305        }
306        zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
307                (zoomStartX + zoomCenterX - (width >> 1) << zoomAmount),
308                width >> 1), (width << zoom + zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
309//        int oldZoomY = zoomStartY;
310        zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
311                (zoomStartY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount),
312                height >> 1), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
313//        System.out.printf("zoomIn, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d, oldZoomY: %d, unedited: %d, upperCap: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY,
314//                oldZoomY, (oldZoomY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
315        zoom += zoomAmount;
316        if(startCacheX.isEmpty())
317        {
318            startCacheX.add(0);
319            startCacheY.add(0);
320        }
321        else {
322            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.peek() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom - 1) - (width >> zoom + 1),
323                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
324            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.peek() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom - 1) - (height >> zoom + 1),
325                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
326        }
327        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
328                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
329                usedWidth = width >> zoom, usedHeight = height >> zoom,
330                landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
331        rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
332    }
333
334    protected abstract void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
335                                       double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB);
336    /**
337     * Given a latitude and longitude in radians (the conventional way of describing points on a globe), this gets the
338     * (x,y) Coord on the map projection this generator uses that corresponds to the given lat-lon coordinates. If this
339     * generator does not represent a globe (if it is toroidal, for instance) or if there is no "good way" to calculate
340     * the projection for a given lat-lon coordinate, this returns null. The default implementation always returns null.
341     * If this is a supported operation and the parameters are valid, this returns a Coord with x between 0 and
342     * {@link #width}, and y between 0 and {@link #height}, both exclusive. Automatically wraps the Coord's values using
343     * {@link #wrapX(int, int)} and {@link #wrapY(int, int)}.
344     * @param latitude the latitude, from {@code Math.PI * -0.5} to {@code Math.PI * 0.5}
345     * @param longitude the longitude, from {@code 0.0} to {@code Math.PI * 2.0}
346     * @return the point at the given latitude and longitude, as a Coord with x between 0 and {@link #width} and y between 0 and {@link #height}, or null if unsupported
347     */
348    public Coord project(double latitude, double longitude)
349    {
350        return null;
351    }
352
353    public int codeHeight(final double high)
354    {
355        if(high < deepWaterUpper)
356            return 0;
357        if(high < mediumWaterUpper)
358            return 1;
359        if(high < shallowWaterUpper)
360            return 2;
361        if(high < coastalWaterUpper)
362            return 3;
363        if(high < sandUpper)
364            return 4;
365        if(high < grassUpper)
366            return 5;
367        if(high < forestUpper)
368            return 6;
369        if(high < rockUpper)
370            return 7;
371        return 8;
372    }
373    protected final int decodeX(final int coded)
374    {
375        return coded % width;
376    }
377    protected final int decodeY(final int coded)
378    {
379        return coded / width;
380    }
381    public int wrapX(final int x, final int y)  {
382        return (x + width) % width;
383    }
384    public int wrapY(final int x, final int y)  {
385        return (y + height) % height;
386    }

644
645    public interface BiomeMapper
646    {
647        /**
648         * Gets the most relevant biome code for a given x,y point on the map. Some mappers can store more than one
649         * biome at a location, but only the one with the highest influence will be returned by this method. Biome codes
650         * are always ints, and are typically between 0 and 60, both inclusive; they are meant to be used as indices
651         * into a table of names or other objects that identify a biome, accessible via {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}.
652         * Although different classes may define biome codes differently, they should all be able to be used as indices
653         * into the String array returned by getBiomeNameTable().
654         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
655         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
656         * @return an int that can be used as an index into the array returned by {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}
657         */
658        int getBiomeCode(int x, int y);
659
660        /**
661         * Gets a heat code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
662         * implementations may use more or less detail for heat codes, but 0 is always the coldest code used, and the
663         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the hottest code used.
664         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
665         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
666         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how hot an area is, with 0 as coldest
667         */
668        int getHeatCode(int x, int y);
669        /**
670         * Gets a moisture code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
671         * implementations may use more or less detail for moisture codes, but 0 is always the driest code used, and the
672         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the wettest code used. Some
673         * implementations may allow seasonal change in moisture, e.g. monsoon seasons, to be modeled differently from
674         * average precipitation in an area, but the default assumption is that this describes the average amount of
675         * moisture (rain, humidity, and possibly snow/hail or other precipitation) that an area receives annually.
676         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
677         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
678         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how much moisture an area tends to receive, with 0 as driest
679         */
680        int getMoistureCode(int x, int y);
681
682        /**
683         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to. A
684         * sample table is in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper#biomeTable}; the 61-element array format documented for that
685         * field is encouraged for implementing classes if they use 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and track
686         * rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained
687         * with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}, or for some implementing classes other methods may provide more
688         * detailed information.
689         * @return a String array that often contains 61 elements, to be used with biome codes as indices.
690         */
691        String[] getBiomeNameTable();
692        /**
693         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
694         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
695         * retrieved with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)} and used as indices into {@link #getBiomeNameTable()} or a
696         * custom biome table.
697         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
698         */
699        void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world);
700    }
701    /**
702     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you only need a single value to describe a biome, such
703     * as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest".
704     * <br>
705     * To use: 1, Construct a SimpleBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
706     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
707     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used as an index
708     * into the {@link #biomeTable} static field to get a String name for a biome type, or used with an alternate biome
709     * table of your design. Biome tables in this case are 61-element arrays organized into groups of 6 elements, with
710     * the last element reserved for empty space where the map doesn't cover (as with some map projections). Each
711     * group goes from the coldest temperature first to the warmest temperature last in the group. The first group of 6
712     * contains the dryest biomes, the next 6 are medium-dry, the next are slightly-dry, the next slightly-wet, then
713     * medium-wet, then wettest. After this first block of dry-to-wet groups, there is a group of 6 for coastlines, a
714     * group of 6 for rivers, a group of 6 for lakes, a group of 6 for oceans, and then one element for space outside
715     * the map. The last element, with code 60, is by convention the String "Empty", but normally the code should be
716     * enough to tell that a space is off-map. This also assigns moisture codes and heat codes from 0 to 5 for each
717     * cell, which may be useful to simplify logic that deals with those factors.
718     */
719    public static class SimpleBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
720    {
721        /**
722         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
723         */
724        public int[][] heatCodeData,
725        /**
726         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
727         */
728        moistureCodeData,
729        /**
730         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 60 inclusive. You can use {@link #biomeTable} to look up
731         * String names for biomes, or construct your own table as you see fit (see docs in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}).
732         */
733        biomeCodeData;
734
735        @Override
736        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
737            return biomeCodeData[x][y];
738        }
739
740        @Override
741        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
742            return heatCodeData[x][y];
743        }
744
745        @Override
746        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
747            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
748        }
749
750        /**
751         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
752         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
753         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
754         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
755         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
756         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
757         */
758        @Override
759        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
760            return biomeTable;
761        }
762
763        public static final double
764                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
765                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
766                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
767                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,    // 3
768                warmerValueLower = 0.69,   warmerValueUpper = 0.85,  // 4
769                warmestValueLower = 0.85,  warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
770
771        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
772                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
773                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
774                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
775                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
776                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
777
778        /**
779         * The default biome table to use with biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned based on
780         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
781         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
782         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest), then oceans (coldest to warmest), and
783         * lastly a single "biome" for empty space outside the map (meant for projections that don't fill a rectangle).
784         */
785        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
786                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
787                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
788                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
789                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
790                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
791                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
792                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
793                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
794                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
795                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
796                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
797                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
798        };
799
800        /**
801         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
802         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
803         */
804        public SimpleBiomeMapper()
805        {
806            heatCodeData = null;
807            moistureCodeData = null;
808            biomeCodeData = null;
809        }
810
811        /**
812         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
813         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
814         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used as indices into {@link #biomeTable} or a custom biome table.
815         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
816         */
817        @Override
818        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
819            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
820                return;
821            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
822                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
823            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
824                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
825            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
826                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
827            final double i_hot = (world.maxHeat == world.minHeat) ? 1.0 : 1.0 / (world.maxHeat - world.minHeat);
828            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
829                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
830                    final double hot = (world.heatData[x][y] - world.minHeat) * i_hot, moist = world.moistureData[x][y];
831                    final int heightCode = world.heightCodeData[x][y];
832                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
833                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
834                        continue;
835                    }
836                    int hc, mc;
837                    boolean isLake = false,// world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
838                            isRiver = false;// world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
839                    if(heightCode < 4) {
840                        mc = 9;
841                    }
842                    else if (moist > wetterValueUpper) {
843                        mc = 5;
844                    } else if (moist > wetValueUpper) {
845                        mc = 4;
846                    } else if (moist > dryValueUpper) {
847                        mc = 3;
848                    } else if (moist > drierValueUpper) {
849                        mc = 2;
850                    } else if (moist > driestValueUpper) {
851                        mc = 1;
852                    } else {
853                        mc = 0;
854                    }
855
856                    if (hot > warmerValueUpper) {
857                        hc = 5;
858                    } else if (hot > warmValueUpper) {
859                        hc = 4;
860                    } else if (hot > coldValueUpper) {
861                        hc = 3;
862                    } else if (hot > colderValueUpper) {
863                        hc = 2;
864                    } else if (hot > coldestValueUpper) {
865                        hc = 1;
866                    } else {
867                        hc = 0;
868                    }
869
870                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
871                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
872                    biomeCodeData[x][y] = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
873                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
874                }
875            }
876        }
877    }
878    /**
879     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you want an area's biome to be a combination of two
880     * main biome types, such as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest", with the biomes varying in weight between areas.
881     * <br>
882     * To use: 1, Construct a DetailedBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
883     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
884     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used with the
885     * extract methods in this class to get various information from it (these are {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
886     * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, {@link #extractPartA(int)}, {@link #extractPartB(int)}, and
887     * {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}). You can get predefined names for biomes using the extractBiome methods (these
888     * names can be changed in {@link #biomeTable}), or raw indices into some (usually 61-element) collection or array
889     * with the extractPart methods. The extractMixAmount() method gets a float that is the amount by which biome B
890     * affects biome A; if this is higher than 0.5, then biome B is the "dominant" biome in the area.
891     */
892    public static class DetailedBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
893    {
894        /**
895         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
896         */
897        public int[][] heatCodeData,
898        /**
899         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
900         */
901        moistureCodeData,
902        /**
903         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, using one int to store the codes for two biomes and the degree by which
904         * the second biome affects the first. These codes can be used with methods in this class like
905         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two
906         * dominant biomes in an area, called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B
907         * affects biome A.
908         */
909        biomeCodeData;
910
911        @Override
912        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
913            int code = biomeCodeData[x][y];
914            if(code < 0x2000000) return code & 1023;
915            return (code >>> 10) & 1023;
916        }
917
918        @Override
919        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
920            return heatCodeData[x][y];
921        }
922
923        @Override
924        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
925            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
926        }
927
928        /**
929         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
930         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
931         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
932         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
933         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
934         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
935         */
936        @Override
937        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
938            return biomeTable;
939        }
940
941        public static final double
942                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
943                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
944                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
945                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,     // 3
946                warmerValueLower = 0.69,    warmerValueUpper = 0.85,   // 4
947                warmestValueLower = 0.85,   warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
948
949        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
950                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
951                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
952                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
953                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
954                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
955
956        /**
957         * The default biome table to use with parts of biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned by
958         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
959         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
960         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest). The last is reserved for empty space.
961         * <br>
962         * Unlike with {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}, you cannot use a biome code directly from biomeCodeData as an index
963         * into this in almost any case; you should pass the biome code to one of the extract methods.
964         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)} or {@link #extractBiomeB(int)} will work if you want a biome name, or
965         * {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} should be used if you want a non-coded int that
966         * represents one of the biomes' indices into something like this. You can also get the amount by which biome B
967         * is affecting biome A with {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}.
968         */
969        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
970                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
971                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
972                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
973                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
974                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
975                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
976                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
977                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
978                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
979                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
980                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
981                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
982        };
983
984        /**
985         * Gets the int stored in part A of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
986         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
987         * for should have a length of at least 61.
988         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
989         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part A; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
990         */
991        public int extractPartA(int biomeCode)
992        {
993            return biomeCode & 1023;
994        }
995        /**
996         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part A of the given biome code.
997         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
998         * @return a String that names the biome in part A of biomeCode, or "Empty" if none can be found
999         */
1000        public String extractBiomeA(int biomeCode)
1001        {
1002            biomeCode &= 1023;
1003            if(biomeCode < 60)
1004                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1005            return "Empty";
1006        }
1007        /**
1008         * Gets the int stored in part B of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1009         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1010         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1011         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1012         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part B; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1013         */
1014        public int extractPartB(int biomeCode)
1015        {
1016            return (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1017        }
1018
1019        /**
1020         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part B of the given biome code.
1021         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1022         * @return a String that names the biome in part B of biomeCode, or "Ocean" if none can be found
1023         */
1024        public String extractBiomeB(int biomeCode)
1025        {
1026            biomeCode = (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1027            if(biomeCode < 60)
1028                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1029            return "Empty";
1030        }
1031
1032        /**
1033         * This gets the portion of a biome code that represents the amount of mixing between two biomes.
1034         * Biome codes are normally obtained from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, and aren't very usable on their own
1035         * without calling methods like this, {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, and {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}. This returns
1036         * a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive), with 0.0f meaning biome B has no effect on an area and
1037         * biome A is the only one used, 0.5f meaning biome A and biome B have equal effect, and 0.75f meaning biome B
1038         * has most of the effect, three-fourths of the area, and biome A has less, one-fourth of the area.
1039         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1040         * @return a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive) representing mixing of biome B into biome A
1041         */
1042        public float extractMixAmount(int biomeCode)
1043        {
1044            return (biomeCode >>> 20) * 0x1p-10f;
1045        }
1046
1047        /**
1048         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
1049         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
1050         */
1051        public DetailedBiomeMapper()
1052        {
1053            heatCodeData = null;
1054            moistureCodeData = null;
1055            biomeCodeData = null;
1056        }
1057
1058        /**
1059         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
1060         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
1061         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used with methods in this class like {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
1062         * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two dominant biomes in an area,
1063         * called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B affects biome A.
1064         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
1065         */
1066        @Override
1067        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
1068            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
1069                return;
1070            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1071                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1072            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1073                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1074            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1075                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1076            final int[][] heightCodeData = world.heightCodeData;
1077            final double[][] heatData = world.heatData, moistureData = world.moistureData, heightData = world.heightData;
1078            int hc, mc, heightCode, bc;
1079            double hot, moist, high, i_hot = 1.0 / world.maxHeat, fresh;
1080            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
1081                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
1082
1083                    heightCode = heightCodeData[x][y];
1084                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
1085                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 61;
1086                        continue;
1087                    }
1088                    hot = heatData[x][y];
1089                    moist = moistureData[x][y];
1090                    high = heightData[x][y];
1091//                    fresh = world.freshwaterData[x][y];
1092                    boolean isLake = false,//world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
1093                            isRiver = false;//world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
1094                    if (moist >= (wettestValueUpper - (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1095                        mc = 5;
1096                    } else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper - (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1097                        mc = 4;
1098                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper - (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1099                        mc = 3;
1100                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper - (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1101                        mc = 2;
1102                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper - (driestValueUpper) * 0.2)) {
1103                        mc = 1;
1104                    } else {
1105                        mc = 0;
1106                    }
1107
1108                    if (hot >= (warmestValueUpper - (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1109                        hc = 5;
1110                    } else if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper - (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1111                        hc = 4;
1112                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper - (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1113                        hc = 3;
1114                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper - (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1115                        hc = 2;
1116                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper - (coldestValueUpper) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1117                        hc = 1;
1118                    } else {
1119                        hc = 0;
1120                    }
1121
1122                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
1123                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
1124                    bc = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
1125                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
1126
1127                    if(heightCode < 4) {
1128                        mc = 9;
1129                    }
1130                    else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper + (wettestValueUpper - wettestValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1131                        mc = 5;
1132                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper + (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1133                        mc = 4;
1134                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper + (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1135                        mc = 3;
1136                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper + (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1137                        mc = 2;
1138                    } else if (moist >= (driestValueUpper + (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1139                        mc = 1;
1140                    } else {
1141                        mc = 0;
1142                    }
1143
1144                    if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper + (warmestValueUpper - warmestValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1145                        hc = 5;
1146                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper + (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1147                        hc = 4;
1148                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper + (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1149                        hc = 3;
1150                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper + (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1151                        hc = 2;
1152                    } else if (hot >= (coldestValueUpper + (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1153                        hc = 1;
1154                    } else {
1155                        hc = 0;
1156                    }
1157
1158                    bc |= (hc + mc * 6) << 10;
1159                    if(heightCode < 4)
1160                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)((heightData[x][y] + 1.0) * 1000.0) << 20;
1161                    else if (isRiver || isLake)
1162                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)(moist * 358.4 + 665.0) << 20;
1163                    else
1164                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int) ((heightCode == 4)
1165                                ? (sandUpper - high) * 10240.0 // multiplier affected by changes to sandLower
1166                                : NumberTools.sway((high + moist) * (4.1 + high - hot)) * 512 + 512) << 20;
1167                }
1168            }
1169        }
1170    }
1171
1172    /**
1173     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that tiles both east-to-west and north-to-south. It tends
1174     * to not appear distorted like {@link SphereMap} does in some areas, even though this is inaccurate for a
1175     * rectangular projection of a spherical world (that inaccuracy is likely what players expect in a map, though).
1176     * <a href="http://squidpony.github.io/SquidLib/DetailedWorldMapRiverDemo.png" >Example map</a>.
1177     */
1178    public static class TilingMap extends WorldMapGenerator {
1179        //protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.5, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.8, moistureFreq = 2.9, otherFreq = 4.5;
1180//        protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.175, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.3, moistureFreq = 2.4, otherFreq = 3.5;
1181        protected static final double terrainFreq = 0.95, terrainRidgedFreq = 3.1, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375;
1182        private double minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1183                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1184                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1185
1186        public final Noise4D terrain, terrainRidged, heat, moisture, otherRidged;
1187
1188        /**
1189         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1190         * as north-to-south. Always makes a 256x256 map.
1191         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1192         * If you were using {@link TilingMap#TilingMap(long, int, int, Noise4D, double)}, then this would be the
1193         * same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, FastNoise.instance, 1.0}.
1194         */
1195        public TilingMap() {
1196            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, FastNoise.instance, 1.0);
1197        }
1198
1199        /**
1200         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1201         * as north-to-south.
1202         * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
1203         * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
1204         * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1205         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1206         *
1207         * @param mapWidth  the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1208         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1209         */
1210        public TilingMap(int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1211            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight, FastNoise.instance, 1.0);
1212        }
1213
1214        /**
1215         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1216         * as north-to-south.
1217         * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
1218         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
1219         * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1220         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1221         *
1222         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1223         * @param mapWidth    the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1224         * @param mapHeight   the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1225         */
1226        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1227            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, FastNoise.instance, 1.0);
1228        }
1229
1230        /**
1231         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1232         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and a noise generator (a
1233         * {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}. The {@code initialSeed}
1234         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call
1235         * {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom
1236         * in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1237         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1238         * times. The detail level, which is the {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter that can be passed to another
1239         * constructor, is always 1.0 with this constructor.
1240         *
1241         * @param initialSeed      the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1242         * @param mapWidth         the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1243         * @param mapHeight        the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1244         * @param noiseGenerator   an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, recommended to be {@link FastNoise#instance}
1245         */
1246        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator) {
1247            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, noiseGenerator, 1.0);
1248        }
1249
1250        /**
1251         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1252         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and parameters for noise
1253         * generation (a {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}, and a
1254         * multiplier on how many octaves of noise to use, with 1.0 being normal (high) detail and higher multipliers
1255         * producing even more detailed noise when zoomed-in). The {@code initialSeed} parameter may or may not be used,
1256         * since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map
1257         * cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1258         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1259         * times. The {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter should probably be no lower than 0.5, but can be arbitrarily
1260         * high if you're willing to spend much more time on generating detail only noticeable at very high zoom;
1261         * normally 1.0 is fine and may even be too high for maps that don't require zooming.
1262         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1263         * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1264         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1265         * @param noiseGenerator an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, almost always {@link FastNoise}
1266         * @param octaveMultiplier used to adjust the level of detail, with 0.5 at the bare-minimum detail and 1.0 normal
1267         */
1268        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator, double octaveMultiplier) {
1269            super(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight);
1270            terrain = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 8), terrainFreq);
1271            terrainRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 10), terrainRidgedFreq);
1272            heat = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 3), heatFreq);
1273            moisture = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 4), moistureFreq);
1274            otherRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 6), otherFreq);
1275        }
1276
1277        protected void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
1278                                  double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB)
1279        {
1280            boolean fresh = false;
1281            if(cacheA != stateA || cacheB != stateB || landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
1282            {
1283                minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1284                maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1285                minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1286                maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1287                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1288                maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1289                minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1290                maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1291                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1292                maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1293                minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1294                maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1295                cacheA = stateA;
1296                cacheB = stateB;
1297                fresh = true;
1298            }
1299            rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
1300            long seedA = rng.nextLong(), seedB = rng.nextLong(), seedC = rng.nextLong();
1301            int t;
1302
1303            landModifier = (landMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.1875) + 0.99 : landMod;
1304            heatModifier = (heatMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.45) * (rng.nextDouble()-0.5) + 1.1 : heatMod;
1305
1306            double p, q,
1307                    ps, pc,
1308                    qs, qc,
1309                    h, temp,
1310                    i_w = 6.283185307179586 / width, i_h = 6.283185307179586 / height,
1311                    xPos = startX, yPos = startY, i_uw = usedWidth / (double)width, i_uh = usedHeight / (double)height;
1312            double[] trigTable = new double[width << 1];
1313            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++, xPos += i_uw) {
1314                p = xPos * i_w;
1315                trigTable[x<<1]   = NumberTools.sin(p);
1316                trigTable[x<<1|1] = NumberTools.cos(p);
1317            }
1318            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1319                q = yPos * i_h;
1320                qs = NumberTools.sin(q);
1321                qc = NumberTools.cos(q);
1322                for (int x = 0, xt = 0; x < width; x++) {
1323                    ps = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.sin(p);
1324                    pc = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.cos(p);
1325                    heightData[x][y] = (h = terrain.getNoiseWithSeed(pc +
1326                                    terrainRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs,seedB - seedA) * 0.25,
1327                            ps, qc, qs, seedA) + landModifier - 1.0);
1328                    heatData[x][y] = (p = heat.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc
1329                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedB + seedC)
1330                            , qs, seedB));
1331                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = moisture.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs
1332                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedC + seedA)
1333                            , seedC));
1334                    minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, h);
1335                    maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, h);
1336                    if(fresh) {
1337                        minHeight = Math.min(minHeight, h);
1338                        maxHeight = Math.max(maxHeight, h);
1339
1340                        minHeat0 = Math.min(minHeat0, p);
1341                        maxHeat0 = Math.max(maxHeat0, p);
1342
1343                        minWet0 = Math.min(minWet0, temp);
1344                        maxWet0 = Math.max(maxWet0, temp);
1345
1346                    }
1347                }
1348                minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, minHeight);
1349                maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, maxHeight);
1350
1351            }
1352            double heightDiff = 2.0 / (maxHeightActual - minHeightActual),
1353                    heatDiff = 0.8 / (maxHeat0 - minHeat0),
1354                    wetDiff = 1.0 / (maxWet0 - minWet0),
1355                    hMod,
1356                    halfHeight = (height - 1) * 0.5, i_half = 1.0 / halfHeight;
1357            double minHeightActual0 = minHeightActual;
1358            double maxHeightActual0 = maxHeightActual;
1359            yPos = startY;
1360            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1361            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1362
1363            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1364                temp = Math.abs(yPos - halfHeight) * i_half;
1365                temp *= (2.4 - temp);
1366                temp = 2.2 - temp;
1367                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1368//                    heightData[x][y] = (h = (heightData[x][y] - minHeightActual) * heightDiff - 1.0);
1369//                    minHeightActual0 = Math.min(minHeightActual0, h);
1370//                    maxHeightActual0 = Math.max(maxHeightActual0, h);
1371                    h = heightData[x][y];
1372                    heightCodeData[x][y] = (t = codeHeight(h));
1373                    hMod = 1.0;
1374                    switch (t) {
1375                        case 0:
1376                        case 1:
1377                        case 2:
1378                        case 3:
1379                            h = 0.4;
1380                            hMod = 0.2;
1381                            break;
1382                        case 6:
1383                            h = -0.1 * (h - forestLower - 0.08);
1384                            break;
1385                        case 7:
1386                            h *= -0.25;
1387                            break;
1388                        case 8:
1389                            h *= -0.4;
1390                            break;
1391                        default:
1392                            h *= 0.05;
1393                    }
1394                    heatData[x][y] = (h = (((heatData[x][y] - minHeat0) * heatDiff * hMod) + h + 0.6) * temp);
1395                    if (fresh) {
1396                        ps = Math.min(ps, h); //minHeat0
1397                        pc = Math.max(pc, h); //maxHeat0
1398                    }
1399                }
1400            }
1401            if(fresh)
1402            {
1403                minHeat1 = ps;
1404                maxHeat1 = pc;
1405            }
1406            heatDiff = heatModifier / (maxHeat1 - minHeat1);
1407            qs = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1408            qc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1409            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1410            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1411
1412
1413            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1414                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1415                    heatData[x][y] = (h = ((heatData[x][y] - minHeat1) * heatDiff));
1416                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = (moistureData[x][y] - minWet0) * wetDiff);
1417                    if (fresh) {
1418                        qs = Math.min(qs, h);
1419                        qc = Math.max(qc, h);
1420                        ps = Math.min(ps, temp);
1421                        pc = Math.max(pc, temp);
1422                    }
1423                }
1424            }
1425            if(fresh)
1426            {
1427                minHeat = qs;
1428                maxHeat = qc;
1429                minWet = ps;
1430                maxWet = pc;
1431            }
1432            landData.refill(heightCodeData, 4, 999);
1433            /*
1434            if(generateRivers) {
1435                if (fresh) {
1436                    addRivers();
1437                    riverData.connect8way().thin().thin();
1438                    lakeData.connect8way().thin();
1439                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1440                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1441                } else {
1442                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1443                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1444                    int stx = (zoomStartX >> (zoom)) - (width >> 1),
1445                            sty = (zoomStartY >> (zoom)) - (height >> 1);
1446                    for (int i = 1; i <= zoom; i++) {
1447//                        int stx = (startCacheX.get(i) - startCacheX.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1),
1448//                                sty = (startCacheY.get(i) - startCacheY.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1);
1449                        if ((i & 3) == 3) {
1450                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1451                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.4));
1452                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1453                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.55));
1454                        } else {
1455                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1456                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.5));
1457                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1458                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.7));
1459                        }
1460                    }
1461                }
1462            }
1463            */
1464        }

1467    /**
1468     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that distorts the map as it nears the poles, expanding the
1469     * smaller-diameter latitude lines in extreme north and south regions so they take up the same space as the equator;
1470     * this counteracts certain artifacts that are common in Simplex noise world maps by using a 4D noise call to
1471     * generate terrain, using a normal 3D noise call's result as the extra 4th dimension. This generator allows
1472     * choosing a {@link Noise3D}, which is used for most of the generation. This is ideal for projecting onto a 3D
1473     * sphere, which could squash the poles to counteract the stretch this does. You might also want to produce an oval
1474     * map that more-accurately represents the changes in the diameter of a latitude line on a spherical world; you
1475     * should use {@link EllipticalMap} or {@link EllipticalHammerMap} for this.
1476     * {@link HyperellipticalMap} is also a nice option because it can project onto a shape between a
1477     * rectangle (like this class) and an ellipse (like EllipticalMap), with all-round sides.
1478     * <a href="http://i.imgur.com/wth01QD.png">Example map, showing distortion</a>
1479     */
1480    @Beta
1481    public static class SphereMap extends WorldMapGenerator {
1482        protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.45, terrainRidgedFreq = 3.1, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375;
1483        //protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.65, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.8, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375, riverRidgedFreq = 21.7;
1484        private double minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1485                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1486                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1487
1488        public final Noise3D terrain, heat, moisture, otherRidged, terrainLayered;
1489        public final double[][] xPositions,
1490                yPositions,
1491                zPositions;
1492

1494        /**
1495         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used to wrap a sphere (as with a texture on a
1496         * 3D model), with seamless east-west wrapping, no north-south wrapping, and distortion that causes the poles to
1497         * have significantly-exaggerated-in-size features while the equator is not distorted.
1498         * Always makes a 256x128 map.
1499         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1500         * If you were using {@link SphereMap#SphereMap(long, int, int, Noise3D, double)}, then this would be the
1501         * same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 128, FastNoise.instance, 1.0}.
1502         */
1503        public SphereMap() {
1504            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 128, FastNoise.instance, 1.0);
1505        }

1507        /**
1508         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used to wrap a sphere (as with a texture on a
1509         * 3D model), with seamless east-west wrapping, no north-south wrapping, and distortion that causes the poles to
1510         * have significantly-exaggerated-in-size features while the equator is not distorted.
1511         * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
1512         * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
1513         * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1514         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1515         *
1516         * @param mapWidth  the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1517         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1518         */
1519        public SphereMap(int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1520            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight,  FastNoise.instance,1.0);
1521        }
